user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  const char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  const char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  char *header_malloced;
  char *value_malloced;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  header_malloced = malloc (header_len + 1);
  if (NULL == header_malloced)
    return false;

  memcpy (header_malloced, header, header_len);
  header_malloced[header_len] = 0;

  value_malloced = malloc (content_len + 1);
  if (NULL != value_malloced)
  {
    memcpy (value_malloced, content, content_len);
    value_malloced[content_len] = 0;

    if (MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (response, kind,
                                          header_malloced, header_len,
                                          value_malloced, content_len))
      return true; /* Success exit point */

    free (value_malloced);
  }
  free (header_malloced);

  return false; /* Failure exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_:
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Direct recursion would be a function calling itself by name; indirect recursion requires a call chain returning to the original function. I have selected: the whole MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ function and its call to MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_, and the whole MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ function plus its calls to MHD_calloc_ and _MHD_insert_header_last. These fragments cover the visible call chain that could form an indirect recursion back to MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_.

Other fragments were not included because they cannot form recursion by themselves: calls to malloc, memcpy, free are standard library operations and do not call back into these functions; simple assignments (hdr->...), zero-termination of strings (header_malloced[header_len] = 0), returns, and the mhd_assert macro (defined as ((void)0)) are not function calls that could create a recursion cycle. Therefore those parts need not be investigated for Rule 17.2 based on the provided code.
